ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MEDISAVE
(Use for angioplasty procedure)


    1. Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health (a) the rationale for disallowing the use of Medisave to pay for the costs of inserting stents in an angioplasty procedure when Medisave can be used for other charges related to this procedure and (b) will his Ministry review this policy.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to clarify that Medisave can be used to pay for stents in an angioplasty procedure. Surgical implants, including stents, are eligible for Medisave claims as part of the total hospital bill, subject to the daily withdrawal limit of $300. Implants can also be claimed under MediShield and Medisave-approved insurance schemes, where the maximum amount claimable ranges from $1,500 to $3,500, in addition to other claims such as room and board and surgery procedures. Together, Medisave and MediShield can cover more than 80% of the average B2 patient bill for a coronary angioplasty procedure involving stent implants.

    The Ministry of Health, however, recognises that the costs of implants vary considerably, depending on the type of medical condition treated. Therefore, the current Medisave withdrawal limits and

Column: 1671

MediShield claimable limits may not fully cater for the wide range in costs between treatments for different medical conditions.

    To address this, the Ministry will reset the Medisave withdrawal limits and MediShield Claimable limits for inpatient and day surgery cases to be based on Diagnosis-Related-Groups (DRGs) next year. This will better reflect the resources needed to treat the different medical conditions, and will allow patients to withdraw or claim more from Medisave or MediShield, for medical conditions that are on the average more expensive to treat. Under this new structure, Medisave and MediShield would be able to fully cover the bills for most subsidised patients undergoing coronary angioplasty procedures with stent implants. The price of medical technology like stents can vary greatly and equally effective stents can be priced differently by manufacturers. If a patient wants a more expensive stent, Medisave and MediShield will not fully cover the patient's bill.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the stent insertion procedure that can be done in a day surgery be applicable for Medisave application as well?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The answer is yes.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): I would like to ask the Minister whether the review, where the payment will be based on diagnosis-related illnesses, will still be subject to a maximum claim amount. The Minister did mention that the costs of the stents vary. To my knowledge, very often, the patient does not have enough understanding to know what the cost of the best kind of stent that is necessary for an angioplasty procedure is and, therefore, would take advice from the doctors. So, the cost of the procedure and the stent is something that is very much not within the control of the patient. Could the Minister therefore consider that point as well?

Column: 1672



    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member has raised three related issues.

    The first issue, as I explained, is the way we structure the withdrawal limits of the claims. Today, it is a very blunt instrument where we have a table of operations with seven categories. When we change over to the DRGs next year, this will be a more responsive system, with over 600 categories. So, the claims will be more related to the type of medical treatment undertaken. But that alone will not solve the problem.

    The second issue is what is the withdrawal limit that we allow. As long as we have Medisave, which is a compulsory savings scheme, it cannot be a free-for-all. So, the Ministry will continue to set some kind of a maximum, because the whole idea of Medisave is to be able to provide savings for the future medical needs, especially when one grows old. So, we cannot allow free use of the Medisave. There will continue to be some limits. Of course, we will review these limits regularly to make sure they keep up with the medical technology and changes in medical procedures.

    The third issue is how do we address very expensive medical devices and medical technology. What we have in the Ministry of Health is a procedure by which we review what are considered standard treatment, standard devices and standard drugs. These will be subsidised and these are the kinds of things for which we will allow Medisave to be withdrawn.

    Medical technology changes very rapidly, and there will be non-standard procedures, non-standard devices and non-standard drugs. So, how do we address this? We could take a very strict approach and say, "If they are non-standard, they will not be allowed in our hospitals. If you want, you will have to go to the private hospitals." Or we could take a more liberal approach and offer the patient some choice, eg, "This is the standard that we will subsidise and will allow Medisave withdrawals, but if you want a non-standard drug or non-

Column: 1673

standard device, then you will have to pay the full cost of that", in which case, we must make sure that there is proper financial counselling and that the patient understands what he is in for. On the ground, with thousands of such operations, there could be lapses, and there will be the kind of cases that the hon. Member raised, ie, where the patient may not understand that by selecting a particular stent, he is selecting a very expensive one that costs $6,000 and, later on, when he has to pay for it in cash, he then finds that he cannot afford it. This is the kind of issue we have to address. We are reviewing this and we will lay out the parameters sometime next year.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister whether it is correct to say that the stent insertion procedure is used to treat ischemic heart disease and myocardial infarction, and these two conditions caused 3,243 Singaporeans to die last year, and the second highest incidents of deaths in Singapore? In view of this fact, will his Ministry prioritise and allow patients to have full claim from Medisave or even subsidised for such life-saving procedures?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Stent is almost used as a standard device nowadays, and if you are admitted as a B2 patient and the average stay perhaps is four days, the average B2 patient bill for such a procedure is $4,600. The total amount that can be withdrawn from Medisave and MediShield is about $4,000 or 86%. So, you pay the balance in cash. If you go for a standard procedure involving standard stents, our current rules allow the withdrawal which is about 86%.

    The problem arises when the patient chooses a top-of-the-market stent which costs $6,000, as is the case which I understood from Mdm Halimah. In that case, he had two stents, which cost $12,000. This is obviously way beyond the Medisave limit. This is a non-standard procedure and, therefore, he was asked to pay cash. How do we address this?

    As I have said in my answer, we could say that such things are not allowed in the

Column: 1674

restructured hospitals. If somebody wants to go for these top-of-the-range stents, then please go to the private hospitals. We will then not have such problems in the restructured hospitals. Or we can take a more liberal approach and say, "These are non-standard. If you want them, please be sure you know the financial repercussions", and we make sure we have financial counselling. But I can assure Members that out of the 1,000 cases, there will be lapses or claims of lapses, and we will face these problems.

    So, this is something that we will have to review and we will decide next year whether or not we take a more stringent approach or we still allow this choice in our restructured hospitals.

    Dr Lily Neo: Am I correct to say that the stent insertion procedure can be done as a day surgery, therefore, saving patients hospitalisation costs and is also a good way of reducing hospitals' operating costs? Will the Minister prioritise or encourage patients to have the stent procedure done as a day surgery?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am no doctor. I leave this to the professionals. If the professionals feel that in a particular condition stents can be done in a day surgery, we encourage them to do so in a day surgery. If the professionals say that this is safer done in an in-patient setting, then we will do it in an in-patient setting.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob: Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand what the Minister is saying. I hope that in the review the Minister would also take into consideration this point that while the Government wants to try and persuade people to be prudent in the management of their hospital bills ---

    Mr Speaker: What is your question, Mdm Halimah?

    Mdm Halimah Yacob: My question is: would the Minister also take into account in the review the point that when someone has enough Medisave savings and he wants to use it for a stent and angioplasty procedure which is expensive and he thinks that it is useful for him, then

Column: 1675

he should be given some flexibility to take care of his own interests, although I understand the basic premise of some of the principles there?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: On the use of Medisave, we have to be very clear. There has to be some restraint and discipline and, therefore, there will be some maximum withdrawal limits imposed. I am not prepared to say that everybody is allowed to use his Medisave in whatever way he likes. We can use our cash in whatever way we like but, for Medisave, its purpose is forced savings intended to last us a lifetime and, therefore, it cannot be a free-for-all. Whether or not we allow you to spend your cash freely in the restructured hospitals, that is something that we want to consider. Even if it is your cash, we may not allow you to spend freely in the hospital. We may say, "If you want to spend your cash freely in the hospital, please go to the private hospitals." This is something that we are considering.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Minister has missed my point. My point really is not that we should encourage people to use the Medisave flexibly and freely, but that for life-threatening procedures, such as angioplasty, there should be some flexibility to let the individual decide, if he has enough Medisave savings that he wants to use for that purpose, without too much restriction on the use, ie, for life-saving procedures, not just any frivolous kind of procedures.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have explained in my answer, we have a team of cardiac surgeons and cardiologists who regularly reviews these procedures and makes sure that our list of standard procedures covers all the cost-effective procedures that we want to subvent and that we allow Medisave to be used for. The problem arises because there are claims by manufacturers that if you use this latest stent, it will give you additional benefits. But this is not assessed by our team of experts to be a cost-effective procedure that we want to include under our Medisave list based

Column: 1676

on proper evidence, but it is available on the market. So, do we allow this choice, or do we say, "If you go to a restructured hospital, we will only do those cases which are recommended and assessed by our team of experts"?

TATTOOING PROCEDURES
(Regulation)


    2. Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health, in view of the high risk of infection of unregulated tattooing procedures now freely conducted by untrained persons without any health or safety guidelines will his Ministry (i) regulate the conduct of this procedure; and (ii) consider banning those below 18 years from tattooing themselves unless they have parental consent as is the practice in some countries.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, tattoo practitioners do not come under the purview of the Ministry of Health, as they are not medical practitioners. Services provided by these practitioners, which are non-medical, are therefore not required to be licensed under the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act.

    Nonetheless, if they carry out practices or procedures that are considered medical treatments, ie, they use harmful medical products or they prescribe poisons or controlled drugs, or use unlicensed equipment such as lasers, then they will be in contravention of a number of legislation. The Ministry of Health will then investigate into these tattoo practitioners, if they contravened any of these acts.

    Tattooing procedures carry the risk of transmitting blood-borne diseases, like Hepatitis B, C and HIV. If sterilised needles and other hygiene measures are used, of course, the risk of infection is small.

    Investigations into all the notified cases of blood-borne diseases in Singapore, including HIV, have indicated that none of these reported cases from 1985 to date have acquired the infection from tattooing procedures in Singapore.

Column: 1677



    Under the Infectious Diseases Act, the Ministry of Health has the power to prohibit any person from carrying out any occupation, trade or business if these are conducted in such a manner as is likely to cause the spread of any infectious diseases. If there is any evidence that the practice at any establishment is likely to have caused the spread of an infectious disease, these establishments can be closed down under this Act.

    The Ministry of Health so far has also put in place health education programmes mainly through health education pamphlets, etc, to advise the public on the prevention of transmission of infectious diseases during tattooing. This is to ensure that the public will take the necessary precautions to minimise the chance of infection. However, the best precaution is not to undergo a tattooing itself.

    At this point we feel that it is not necessary to regulate tattooing, nor require those below 18 to get parental consent. However, we will continue to monitor the practice and we will review the situation regularly.

Column: 1677

LITERATURE AS A COMPULSORY SUBJECT IN SCHOOLS


    3. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for Education based on the merits of Literature as endorsed by the Ministry and the Economic Review Committee, if he will (i) consider making Literature a compulsory subject for all students at the upper primary and lower secondary school levels using a range of books to manage the different linguistic abilities of children; and (ii) introduce a compulsory module of Literature for all polytechnic students to give them an all-rounded education.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, currently, all lower secondary students in the Express and Normal (Academic) courses already study Literature. Normal (Technical) students do not study literature as their curriculum is focused on giving them the

Column: 1678

literacy and numeracy skills as well as a technically-oriented foundation to enable them to benefit from further education and training at an Institute of Technical Education (ITE) after 10 years of formal schooling.

    At the primary level, the use of language for literary response and expression is taught as part of the English Language programme. An integral part of the syllabus is the students' exposure to a wide variety of texts appropriate to their needs. This means that our students would have adequate opportunities to read and see how language is used in various texts, including narratives, and to arrive at conclusions about story lines, events and characters. While literature is not a subject in the upper primary curriculum, our children are encouraged to read and such programmes are pervasive in our primary schools and are often conducted in conjunction with our partners in education such as the National Library Board and parent volunteers.

    As for the introduction of Literature into the polytechnic curriculum as a compulsory polytechnic curriculum, our polytechnics are geared towards providing a curriculum that prepares their students for employment opportunities in industry. Their curriculum is constantly reviewed and customised to meet the requirements of industry. Besides this focus, the polytechnics do offer a balanced and well-rounded education. This is done through including subject modules in the curriculum that provide their students with a creative outlook and the ability to exercise and apply critical thinking in their work. In addition, students are exposed to programmes that promote national education and community service. They also participate in co-curricular activities, for example, in sports and the arts. There would therefore not be a need for MOE to require the polytechnics to introduce Literature as a compulsory subject in order to provide students in the polytechnics with a well-rounded education.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Could I ask the Minister how then can we enhance or deepen this

Column: 1679

reading habit especially among the polytechnic students and upper primary students because there have been reports that the standards of ability to converse and dwell and discuss in English are getting lower? What are the efforts we can take on then?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, I disagree with the Member that our English Language standards are getting lower. I think if you look at the usage of English Language in Singapore and you look at the top 5% of English speakers and you compare them with the top 5% of the population 20 years ago, I think they are comparable. If you go down to 15-20% of the population, they are speaking English today. But probably when you get down to about 20% of the population, they were not speaking English 20 years ago. If you get down to 50% of the population, they are speaking English today, not perfect English, not the way the Member speaks English or the Member would like others to speak English, but they are speaking English. Therefore, the English that we hear today, because it is being spoken by a much wider spectrum of Singaporeans, who might never have spoken English before, on average, may be lower. But the English level in Singapore, I think, is indeed higher than it was 20 years ago. So I disagree with the premise of the Member's question.

SYARIAH COURT
(Translation of documents)


    4. Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (a) what is the number of requests for translation of documents and rulings of the Syariah Court from Malay to English; (b) is there an increasing number in such request; (c) does his Ministry find it necessary for future written documents and rulings of the Syariah Court to be given in both Malay and English.

Column: 1680



    The Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Syariah Court started issuing its summonses, correspondences, documents, decrees and orders in English in August 1999. Prior to that, such documents were issued in Malay. The switch was made for the benefit of divorcees who needed to submit the documents for various applications to other Government agencies such as the CPF Board, Immigration and HDB. Before the switch, divorcees had to go to the Supreme Court to translate the documents from Malay to English for a fee. This meant that such families had to incur additional costs, suffer inconvenience and delay. The present arrangement serves the interests of divorcees better. It saves them time and they need not incur additional costs for translations.

    Although important documents such as Court orders are printed in English, the proceedings of the Court are always conducted in either Malay or English, depending on what the divorcees themselves are conversant in. Very often, simultaneous interpreters for Tamil, English or other languages are used to assist parties who do not understand Malay or English. In cases where there is more than one language chosen, the Court will conduct the proceedings in either language and an interpreter will simultaneously interpret into the other language. These interpreters are engaged at the Court's expense, and not by the divorcees.

    The divorcees will thus understand the proceedings, the testimonies and examinations that go on in their presence in court. Subsequently, the orders that are pronounced by the Court in their presence will be in the language that they have chosen. For example, in cases where the divorcees do not understand English, but understand Malay, the Court will conduct the proceedings in Malay and will pronounce its decrees and orders in Malay, whilst the written document reflecting this will be in English.

FOREIGN MAID LEVY


    5. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Manpower whether the

Column: 1681

Ministry plans to increase the foreign maid levy and, if so, whether the Ministry has considered other alternatives other than just increasing the levy.

    The Minister of State for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen) (for the Minister for Manpower): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government announced in May this year that the moratorium on all foreign worker levies, of which foreign domestic workers fall under this category, would be extended until December 2002. We will announce the outcome of the review on the foreign worker levy in early December.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Could the Minister of State give working women in Singapore an assurance that there are real and adequate alternatives in the form of local domestic and nanny or child care services available before any increases in foreign maid levy are decided upon?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, to give that assurance means that you will have to answer a number of needs. I think we would have painted ourselves in a corner if we had worked on that principle. Yes, it is difficult to raise families when you want to juggle that with your work commitments. Yes, it is also more expensive to hire local help. But we have to balance this with the increasing number of foreign domestic workers that we have already seen. From the moratorium last time, the number of maids has increased by about 20%, so much so that one in eight households currently have a foreign domestic worker. There are social repercussions.

    What we can do is to continue to provide and expand domestic service as affordable alternatives for local households. For example, the CDCs, in particular, the Southeast CDC has piloted training emplacement programmes for various domestic services. These include cleaning, laundry, child care or eldercare. In line with these efforts, we will need to maintain a FDW levy at an appropriate level to moderate household demand for FDWs. But whether this would satisfy the majority of households, and whether this would be an attractive option remains to

Column: 1682

be seen and is relative. But we will continue to expand these efforts so that there are these alternatives.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1999, we imposed a moratorium on the increase in the FDW levy because of the uncertain economic climate. Would the Minister of State agree that the economic climate is still uncertain and likely to be uncertain next year and, therefore, all the more reasons to continue with the moratorium on any increase?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: I agree with the hon. Member that the economic conditions are uncertain. But the other arm of the planning parameter was the rate of increase in the number of foreign domestic workers and despite the moratorium that has increased out of proportion to the households. As I have said, the moratorium continues to stand and when we do review the levy, we will take into consideration these factors and decide then whether there should be an increase of the levy or not.

    Dr Jennifer Lee: As the Minister of State has observed, the number of foreign workers has continued to rise despite the levies. Would it not seem obvious by now, after so many years of experience that we have had, that the answer must be in something other than the levy? Would it not be a better approach therefore to analyse and permit families to have foreign workers based on need rather than by increasing the levy to an extent that it becomes unaffordable?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, to decide between one family and another based on need is an extremely difficult exercise and for society, I would say an invidious one. How would I judge, for example, whether a family with a diabetic mother of a blood sugar of 400 requires less of a foreign domestic worker versus another family who has three children and is making ends meet? Do I then train my officers to cater to each individual, assessing their needs? And upon pronouncement, would I have one happy family versus the other 10 families who have applied based on need who go away

Column: 1683

angry at the system? I think, based on a quota system, and to decide whether one family gets a foreign domestic worker based on another is an extremely difficult exercise. The levy is not a perfect solution. Other countries have tried other means. We will explore these means but I think it will be hard to run away from the conclusion or to arrive at the wrong conclusion that the levies do not work. The levies do moderate demand. But we will take into account these considerations and also the median household income over the last few years as well as the numbers that are in and what numbers we can fix socially which we can accept before arriving at a decision.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Nominated Member): May I ask the Minister of State, for every family that has a maid, there is only one maid in a family. So what kind of social concern is the Minister worried about by having more maids in the country?

    Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the NCMP would have gone through the papers for the last few months, he could not have but seen a number of abuses that we have talked about in this House. Let us say that we have 140,000 foreign domestic workers. Even if you take 1% of households that, for some reason or other, abuse their maids, we are talking about 1,400 maids. Over and above this, there will be repercussions on our social fabric. We cannot run away from the fact that the people are of different origins, different cultural backgrounds, the problems that they have in assimilation and the effect and distortion it creates in our own society.     Sir, the changes proposed in the Report are of fundamental importance to the remaking of the Singapore economy and society.     Sir, the education system of a country cannot be divorced from the country's economic circumstances. For Singapore, our education system has evolved in response to changes to Singapore's economy and society. Prior to our independence in 1965, when we were a British colony and our economy depended on trade and servicing the British garrison in Singapore, there was no real need for widespread education of our people.

    Consequently, the British authorities concentrated on nurturing a small number of English language schools to educate clerks and a few professionals, particularly in medicine and law, to assist the Colonial Government to run what was then basically a simple economy. Consequently, large numbers of Singapore children were educated in vernacular schools, where teaching was conducted in Chinese, Malay and Tamil, and largely outside the purview of the Department of Education.

    After our independence in 1965, the need was for a national integrated system of education, with uniform characteristics which would be taught to all children in Singapore, regardless of their race or language background. A national system of education proved to be enormously difficult to realise, with political disturbances and even communal riots in the

Column: 1733

    A landmark in educational development in Singapore was the adoption by Parliament in March 1979 of the Goh Keng Swee Report on the Ministry of Education which shaped our present education system, with streaming at primary and secondary schools to enable children to study at a pace appropriate to their intellectual abilities. The success of streaming in our schools can be seen in the dramatic fall in the secondary school drop-out rate from 13% of each Primary 1 cohort of students in 1978 to just 2.7% last year. The primary school drop-out rate has similarly fallen from 6% for each cohort of Primary 1 students in 1978 to almost zero - actually, only 0.3% last year.

Our schools in Singapore, whether the elite independent schools or the more numerous neighbourhood schools, are all well-built and well-equipped, and give to every child in Singapore, no matter what is his or her social class or intellectual capability, at least 10 years of basic education, which will enable the child to proceed further to junior college, polytechnic or Institute of Technical Education and, from then, on to university for those with the determination and ability.

    As the Minister for Education from 1985 to 1991, I built on the solid foundation laid down by Dr Goh Keng Swee to fill out the education structure by upgrading our schools' physical infrastructure, improving the training of our teachers, and emphasising the critical role that principals play in motivating and guiding teachers and students in the search for excellence. Over the last 10 years, subsequent Ministers for Education - Mr Lee Yock Suan and, now, RAdm Teo Chee Hean - further improved the system with innovative measures, such as mass customisation and encouraging the learning of critical thinking skills.

We could have carried on with the present system for possibly the next 10 years, making adjustments here and there to meet difficulties or to fill in inadequacies as they arise. Instead, they aggravate the problem by perpetuating practices that should be jettisoned, if a country is to move ahead.

    A vivid example of how small incremental changes do not solve but merely aggravate a basic problem is the response by successive Japanese governments to the chronic problems in the Japanese economy. Japan had an enormous record of economic success for three decades, from the beginning of the 1960s to the end of the 1980s. Japan as Number One, the influential book written by Harvard Professor Ezra Vogel received wide publicity. Nations in search of development were urged to emulate the Japanese way of doing business.
